NWPZ has the largest 12.33 mha area of wheat cultivation; Estimated production 55.82 mt; Productivity 4527 kg/ha; Contributes 41.73% share in total area and 55.82% share in total production of wheat in India
Climatic conditions most ideal; Major part irrigated timely sown conditions (mainly rice–wheat rotation); Irrigated late sown (cotton–wheat in Punjab & Haryana; wheat–sugarcane in western UP)

High cost of inputs; Intensive tillage; Excessive fertilizer & water use; Higher incidence of yellow rust; Terminal heat stress; Decline in water table; Low price of wheat; Erratic power supply; Phalaris minor infestation; Low organic matter in soil; Poor seed quality; Non-availability of quality seed; Chenopodium album infestation; Non-availability of electricity

Value: North Eastern Plains Zone (NEPZ) is an important zone for wheat production covering Eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, West Bengal, Assam and plains of NE states.

8.85 million ha cultivated; estimated production 22.20 mt; average productivity 2509 kg/ha (national average 3424 kg/ha). Yield gap ~30–35%. Occupies 29.95% of total wheat area and accounts for 22.20% of total wheat production in India.
Winter is short, climate humid. Dominant patterns: Rice-wheat, maize-wheat, pulse-wheat. In Bihar: rice-wheat, maize-wheat, pulse-wheat. In Bengal: rice-wheat, potato-wheat.

Small land holdings, inadequate seed availability, lack of info on new technologies, late sowing, temperature fluctuations, high input prices, poor seed quality, non-availability of labour, poor machinery, diseases (spot blotch, brown rust), moisture stress (drought/excess rain), nutrient deficiencies, soil toxicities, waterlogging.
CSAU&A&T Kanpur, NDUA&T Faizabad, BHU-Varanasi – working on stress resilient genotypes and wheat improvement.
Earlier: UP 262, HUW 234. Recent: HD 2967, DBW 14, DBW 39, CBW 38, K 0307, K 1006, HD 2733, NW 5054. High productivity achieved after DBW 187 (2017).
Biofortified: 2 (Table 2.3); Timely sown irrigated: 2 (Table 2.4); Late sown irrigated: 2 (Table 2.4); Very late sown irrigated: 2 (Table 2.4); Timely sown restricted irrigation: 2 (Table 2.4).
Central Zone (CZ) comprises Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Rajasthan (Kota and Udaipur divisions), and Uttar Pradesh (Jhansi division).

8.64 million ha cultivated; production 22.27 mt; average productivity 2578 kg/ha. Accounts for 20.37% of national wheat production, with 31.15% of total wheat area. Third largest wheat producing zone of India.
Wheat is the major crop; faces soil moisture stress and high temperature. Soybean-wheat system is dominant. Climate is hot and dry; high temperature and terminal heat stress prevalent.

High temperature at maturity, limited irrigation, poor seed replacement, low fertilizer use, imbalance use of fertilizer, non-availability of labour, small holdings, water table decline, incidence of diseases/pests (brown rust, aphids, termites), poor quality seed supply, inadequate access to technology, lack of mechanization.
Institutions working on wheat improvement: IARI-RS Indore, JNKVV-RS Powarkheda, SDAU-Jaipur, AU Jodhpur, JAU Junagadh, JNKVV Jabalpur.

CZ Lok 1 – most preferred variety. Other varieties: GW 322, GW 366, HI 1544 (yield ~39.5 q/ha), HI 1634 (late sown, ~45.6 q/ha). Bread wheat with high gluten and premium quality, durum wheat also important.
Biofortified: 4 (1 durum, 3 bread) (Table 2.5); Timely sown irrigated: 5 (2 durum, 3 bread) (Table 2.6); Late sown irrigated: 6 (Table 2.6); Timely sown restricted irrigation: 6 (Table 2.6).

Value: Peninsular Zone (PZ) comprises Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Goa, Tamil Nadu.
0.71 million ha cultivated; estimated production 1.00 mt; productivity 1404 kg/ha. Species: aestivum, durum, dicoccum.

Bread wheat cultivated under irrigated conditions; durum and dicoccum cultivated under rainfed/restricted irrigation. Sorghum-wheat prevalent under rainfed in Western Maharashtra and Vidarbha. Sunflower-wheat sequence in Karnataka; sugarcane-wheat in some parts of Maharashtra and Karnataka. Importance also in Ahmednagar, Kolhapur (Maharashtra) and Belgaum (Karnataka).

High temperature during crop cycle, short growing period (100–110 days vs 140–150 days in NWPZ), low rainfall, irregular power supply, high input cost, labour non-availability, poor electricity, high cost of custom hiring, untimely rains, lack of irrigation, poor access to seed of new varieties, temperature fluctuations.
MPKV-Research Station Niphad, UAS Dharwad, Agharkar Research Institute Pune – active in wheat breeding and productivity improvement.

Earlier cultivars (HD 2189, MACS 2496) gave <40 q/ha. Improved with RAJ 4037, GW 322, NIAW 917 (2001–2012, ~44 q/ha). Late sown: DWR 195, HD 2501 (~33.3 q/ha). HI 977, NIAW 34 (2001–2005, ~36.4 q/ha).
Biofortified: 5 (4 durum, 1 bread) (Table 2.7); Timely sown irrigated: 2 durum (Table 2.8); Timely sown restricted irrigation: 4 (2 bread, 2 durum) (Table 2.8).
